Generalised Distribution Object

Source: R/Distribution.R
Distribution.Rd

A generalised distribution object for defining custom probability distributions as well as serving as the parent class to specific, familiar distributions. Common mathematical and statistical methods for distributions are defined here with approximate numerical calculations (as opposed to analytical results).

Constructor Arguments

ArgumentTypeDetails
namecharacterFull name of distribution.
short_namecharacterShort name to identify distribution.
typeSetIntervalScientific type.
supportSetIntervalDistribution support. See Details.
distrDomainSetIntervalDistribution domain See Details.
symmetriclogicalIs distribution symmetric?
pdffunctionSee Details.
cdffunctionSee Details.
quantilefunctionSee Details.
randfunctionSee Details.
parametersParameterSetSee Details.
decoratorslistR6 decorators to add in construction.
valueSupportcharactercontinuous, discrete, mixture. See Details.
variateFormcharacterunivariate, multivariate, matrixvariate. See Details.
descriptioncharactershort description of distribution.
R62S3logicalif TRUE (default), S3 methods are added for decorators in construction.

Constructor Details

The most basic Distribution object consists of a name and one of pdf/cdf.

If supplied, type, support and distrDomain should be given as an R6 SetInterval object. If none are supplied then the set of Reals is taken to be the type, support and domain of the distribution. If only type is supplied then this is taken to also be the support and domain.

By default, missing pdf, cdf, quantile and rand are not automatically imputed. Use the FunctionImputation decorator to generate these with a selected method.

If the distribution has parameters, then these should be supplied as a ParameterSet. The distribution parameterisation is taken to be whichever parameters are flagged as 'settable', any others in the ParameterSet are automatically updated by a given function. See ParameterSet for more details on construction of a ParameterSet.

decorators is a list of decorators (R6 environments not strings) to decorate the Distribution with in construction. Decorators can also be added after construction. See DistributionDecorator for more details. The R62S3 determines if S3 methods should be added for the given decorator, it is ignored if decorators = NULL.

valueSupport should be one of continuous/discrete/mixture if supplied. variateForm should be one of univariate/multivariate/matrixvariate if supplied. If not given these are automatically filled from type and support.

Math/Stats Methods

MethodDetails
pdf(x1, log = F)Evaluate density/mass at x1
cdf(x1, lower.tail = T, log.p = F)Evaluate distribution function at x1.
quantile(p, lower.tail = T, log.p = F)Evaluate quantile function at p
rand(n)Simulate n draws from distribution
expectation(trafo)Calculate expectation
var()Calculate variance
sd()Calculate standard deviation
cov()Calculate covariance. See Details
cor()Calculate correlation. See Details
median()Calculate median

Other Methods

MethodInput -> OutputDetails
setParameterValue(lst)list -> invisible(self)Set parameter value. See ParameterSet.
liesInSupport(x, all = TRUE)numeric x logical -> logicalDoes x lie in the support of distribution? See Details.
liesInType(x)numeric -> logicalDoes x lie in the type of distribution?
liesInDistrDomain(x)numeric -> logicalDoes x lie in the domain of distribution?

Representation Methods

MethodDetails
strprint()Character representation of print
print()Print method
summary(full = T)Summary method
plot()Plotting method
qqplot()QQ-Plots

Public Methods Details

cov defaults to var for univariate distributions and cor returns NULL.

If liesInSupport(x, all = TRUE) then returns TRUE only if every numeric in vector x lies in the support of the distribution, otherwise returns a vector of logicals.

See also

See SetInterval and SpecialSet for details on Sets and Intervals. See ParameterSet for parameter details. See DistributionDecorator for Decorator details. See Binomial for details on the arguments to pdf/cdf/quantile/rand.
